Last night in class, we discussed the week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World," by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the initial chapter, Casey distinguishes how our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the central force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that centering culture around place could foster a more grounded community. (This is a rough summation, a disclaimer in case my professor or any classmates read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly engaged me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to battle through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I was finding a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs—an uninvited practical joker.

GOP gets scolded on recruitment. Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are being relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville proceeded as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official conducting the swearing-in urged them to visit a voter registration table—a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been premarked to enroll all the new voters as GOP members. All of this appeared suspicious to Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

Urllink, let's all extend a warm welcome to the newest Atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0 from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. It seems to offer a lot of native app goodness. It's important to note that it is not free, which seems to be a hot topic online recently. You can try it for 15 days and then switch to something else, or pay $25 if you decide you like it. A standout feature is that each post is its own entity, which can be moved, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I can easily see how this would delight news tracker enthusiasts. It imports and exports OPML, as expected.

As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (main story unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned a ridiculous hotkey, requiring your hand to travel across the keyboard to use it. It might seem minor, but during combat, it could potentially disrupt your combo.

They significantly improved Shadow Warrior (2013). The boss fights are incredible, and the weapons feel satisfying (perhaps not quite as impressive as DOOM's, but still solid). Enemies aren't too resilient (as long as you handle elemental and upgrade features wisely). The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you get familiar with it, it isn't cumbersome. The elemental system and limited ammo encourage diverse weapon usage. There are many cool, unique weapons that remain effective throughout most of the game. The music is fantastic, particularly the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were made wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't a person who is 1.74m become as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed I can't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game inform me before I create a character, and not even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I believe this Assassin's Creed installment truly mastered the mechanics across the board (ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, etc). I felt much more connected to this character as well. The story begins rather rough but improves significantly as you progress (I think this is true for every AC game personally). Edward was quite an intriguing character, and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this AC game, which I never got from any of the previous ones. Maybe it's because they seemed to have a bigger purpose. They definitely were not required, but they were fun to collect, and you were rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't entirely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the money to purchase gun parts, which is my primary complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun and HRV is an excellent idea. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction model is off-putting for me. If you are comfortable with this model, then by all means, enjoy it. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. On my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus, the aiming reticule is on the small side, and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not typically a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-'em-up elements is great. I've been playing it as often as I can... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting down the game.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I must say this one fits well. The number of units is amazing. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there are a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well; I'm not kidding. However, if anyone is thinking this game is 'easy,' or if you are new to the strategy genre, it might take you some time to master it. Do not get upset; you will lose units. Just plan ahead and always have anti-air and anti-tank capabilities.

I was negatively biased towards this game before I played it, unsure of buying it. The whole portal gun and portals concept seemed odd to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (okay, it's sometimes cheesy). The different story characters each have their own sense of humor. Those unique characters truly have distinct personalities. And the level design is just rad. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Let's begin with the pros and cons, followed by my thoughts on this game.  

**Pros:**  
+ Some of the best characters  
+ Good story  
+ Loads of content  
+ Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like)  
+ You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest)

**Cons:**  
- Bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway)  
- Weird and awkward love scenes  
- Invisible walls  
- There's one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes  

**Neutral:**  
- Your protagonist can't talk, but this isn't necessarily good or bad  

Now for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. So, if you’re an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgic trip for those in their thirties who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallett just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, though some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a bit, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There’s a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service, and when you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. That isn’t too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it’s for DLC, but why is that necessary? It’s irreversible, so now I know a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It’s easily recognizable as a COD clone, except they managed to make the gunplay worse... How is that possible?

4K+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? Excellent port and a great entry point if you're new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I would suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keyboard/mouse setup; both are completely rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to enjoy. Recommended game for all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers.

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, it plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format can be somewhat annoying, as the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies whenever you progress in the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play Batman plus one other character. The ability to use the controller for most segments of the game while switching to mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, becomes quite enjoyable once you master skidding around corners—and when you master that, navigating the city becomes truly enjoyable!

Exceptional AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays wonderfully—great FPS mechanics, engaging story, intriguing characters, exceptional voice acting, and an impressive soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint-hearted—some cutscenes are quite intense. But when a game overall is this outstanding, it's easier to notice the flaws, and here they are as I observed them: - No SLI support—it's baffling. I had to shelve the game until upgrading my card because it ran poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a decent single GPU card. - Frustratingly, small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch, so please overlook any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability. Graphics: The game features a comic-like style, with very sleek presentation and no unnecessary details. The color schemes are well-chosen and work perfectly for this game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without overloading your system. I run this game on an i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card and 8GB memory, and it runs smoothly on Windows 8.1. Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, or with an Xbox controller.

You can see from the hours I've put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's in its own class and should be treated as such. Can't tell you how many times I hear new players complaining about getting killed quickly. Oh, forbid you get shot in the face and die. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. Edit: I've been playing this game for a while now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A good thing to play when you're not feeling CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and absolutely enthralled by this game. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design beautiful, and the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting. I'm intrigued by the story and world, and the puzzles are enjoyable. However, the comedy is the standout feature. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video games, you'll appreciate the jokes, parodies, and references. Even newcomers to RPGs will enjoy the humor. If you've played Final Fantasy VII or X, this game is a must-play. Without giving too much away, I had to stop after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm truly sorry. I try to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed perfect for me, but the execution fell short. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this one completely unintuitive. Even after looking up how to progress, I just didn't find the gameplay fun. Additionally, it lacks a pause button—or if it does have one, I never found it. Given that many sequences are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel this game is more cut scenes than actual gameplay, leaving me drumming my fingers frequently.

This game... Phew, where to even start? It was absolutely beautiful; from story to graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story, but it felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the narrative my character was telling. The gameplay was fantastic, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this; you crafted an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you develop your civilization to achieve a specific goal or "victory". In previous installments, you navigated Earth's timeline, moving through eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and the Modern Age. However, in this game, you're set in the future, embarking on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K adopted a fresh approach, adding innovative mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. One downside is these new features can be overwhelming. What I think could be improved is incorporating additional artwork to enhance the environments experienced during interactions with other leaders.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better and more "realistic" zombie games. It's designed like a survival horror, requiring you to save ammo, heal wounds, and take pills when infected. Additionally, I find the zombies to be well-animated for a free-to-play game. I recommend getting one or two friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or chat with people in the game.

02/07/2014 - It's unfortunate I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game, as from the brief time I've played, I know I'd be hooked if it weren't for these two major issues. No Australian servers - one red bar puts you at a significant disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Combine that with poor ping, and it just ruins the game. Everything artifacts excessively - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never experienced this issue before with this card and thought it might dislike my overclock. I set my GPU back to stock, and it didn't make a difference.

Late last night, I finished this. The story isn't very deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is immersive, and the many collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat offers the right amount of challenge, but it leans more towards the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't satisfying; it's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Accessing previously unreachable places provides a satisfying sense of progression.

'To The Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To The Moon!' Never before have I been so deeply moved yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care at all. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the Doctor Who references are endless.

Bastion is an exceptionally brilliant game with an engaging storyline. Set in a post-calamity world, you begin to rebuild the bastion. There's a multitude of choices in the game—determining what to construct for an advantage, selecting the weapons and power-ups, and choosing drinks for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals proving the apocalypse need not be dull. Best of all, the game features dynamic narration based on your actions. For example, if you pick up a weapon and then swap it for another in the armory, the narration reflects your decision to take along the new weapon.

I originally purchased this game during its early development phase when only "spacebux" was used as currency, and there was no "tech tree." This is when the game was at its best. All the guns were equally overpowered, so there were no imbalance issues; everyone could eliminate opponents at any time. Additionally, the game used to allow unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game boasting "bajillions of guns," they would at least offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for additional slots. At one point, I had around three pages of guns and was planning new ideas, because, for me, that's where the enjoyment came from.

This game was a surprising gem. Often, rave reviews about products can be misleading, but in this case, the reviews truly capture the fun of this neat little game. It's an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. Expecting this pattern to continue, I gave a melee tank a try anyway and was pleasantly surprised with the outcome, prompting me to experiment more as they were unlocked through playing. The art style and interface are charmingly unique. Consequently, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat encounter, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought numerous changes, particularly for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the changes to their beloved character, it's undeniably for the better; this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced to the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is truly charming. It is filled with detail and is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It is serious when necessary but doesn't shy away from funny moments. The character design is impeccable, featuring various personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, a unique concept. With inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I have seen, you can tell it will be good. It has the best soundtrack I've heard in ages.

I am recommending this purely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did not resonate with me. Half the story hinges on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to elicit a reaction from me. Regarding the other half of the game, it attempts to illustrate (literally) a person in mental decline. It addresses obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other themes. In theory, this is a compelling idea. However, the game took me only 10 minutes to complete, even while reading and absorbing every detail I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces you to a concept and then lets you explore it. It's an incredible way to challenge your mind while still having fun. Although this game isn’t very story-heavy, it spawned one of the best popular games of 2011. I still play it and beat it when I’m bored, and I love returning to what laid the foundation for a gaming legend. Gameplay: Portal’s gameplay is simple, at least to describe. You strategically use portals, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one you press, and another that requires a cube to activate.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other quite annoying)—both of which have been resolved, and one fix even increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120—and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range, though granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're using an overkill setup and only getting 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been a long time since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to ranking among my personal favorite RTS games. Combine this with a compelling grand strategy mode and it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do enjoy the intricate RTS games today—think of Civ V and so on. However, such games often cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one complicated game mode.

Undertale combines its elements to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is pleasant, but together they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic, heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes simultaneously, and subverts RPG tropes in the process. And that's without even mentioning the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write entire pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, and in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and it shows in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to master; however, this breadth of strategy offers myriad ways to reach goals and seize opportunities. The game, in my opinion, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself immersed in every session, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the first few hours of play. After these enjoyable hours, you'll notice that what's left is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. A major high point is that the developers work diligently and release semi-frequent updates, often including sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes, and other tweaks/features. It's great for casual play, though it may not hold your attention beyond a few months unless you really enjoy grinding. The upside is that the game is free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.

This game is incredibly boring. I bought it because I thought it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a popular and delightful PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you absorb progressively larger objects to grow and absorb bigger items. However, the gameplay lacks smoothness, the levels aren't inventive, and what it contains is a surreal horror show. It's not an entertaining horror show, but one that makes you feel rather depressed and question whether life is as it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to humans, makes me wonder if the creators had an unusual interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was eager to try this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator about the journey to becoming president? That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts by requiring you to choose a side: Republican or Democrat—no option for independents or third parties. A little disappointed but still hopeful, I continued to explore. I will give the game credit; the character customization, although limited, is quite entertaining to play with. It's the only time you can choose whether or not to wear your head during a campaign. Literally.

The story in Fallout 3 was better. Settlements interfere with the narrative, making babysitting them frustrating instead of allowing you to focus on the story. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be remapped. There are numerous bugs. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point, requiring me to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to earn power armor; it’s basically given to you from the start of the game, with power cores abundantly found in trader shops. The value of power armor is greatly reduced compared to previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and everything about this game is mediocre, except it doesn’t crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It’s very stable compared to Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was extremely overhyped considering how disappointing it is.

My stats (at the time of this review): - 8.6 hrs to finish - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 What I liked: - visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - story is not outstanding, but the ending (after the closing credits) made me not regret spending time on this game What I disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level becomes much harder, leading to a frustrating experience of repeating tasks until success - achievements are too challenging. There are 13 (out of 15) that less than 2.1% of players have achieved!

Pros: +graphics Cons: -bugs (especially in the environment, you may get stuck or your shots might hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy) -game is handholding/babysitting -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are once spotted -enemy accuracy is frustrating, like the first Ghost Warrior -terrible checkpoints and saves -boring story that I couldn't care less about. I will not recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then, I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move on to the next game in my library. Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and I felt liberated upon finishing), I probably won't play until the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; servers are offline, and you can't play. No compres este juego, servidores fuera de línea. No puedes jugar. While I could play, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game: OMFG, just an hour in this game! It's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking is sometimes unfair, but hey, BF3's matchmaking is worse. Newbies and higher-level players weren't real humans; you'd shoot them in the face, and nothing happens!

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle platforming game features a little character with a fez who travels around collecting bits to form a cube while navigating a large branching map. This game is quite entertaining, and completing it is very enjoyable. However, attempting to collect all the cubes and achieve all the accomplishments can be somewhat challenging. To obtain every cube, you'll need to crack codes that must be deciphered—sometimes taking mere seconds or driving you to consult a guide. (*raises hand* I gave up.) The guide, "A Complete Guide to Fez," can be quite helpful!

I can understand why others are drawn to this game, but it wasn't for me. I own a Vive and prefer room-sized games with the controllers. While the game’s universe initially amazed me with its scale, I found that same vastness impeded my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to engage in interesting activities at the start were too steep for my liking. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more gaming time, it might be appealing. However, I lack both and there are many other VR games I'd rather dedicate my time to.

Hands down my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine all the time, you'll have a pouch full of partially full mags. You can't run forever; if you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you catch your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale including EW, so I never experienced the issues some claim with that game. I loved that game, though it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when things went right. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game performs well on medium settings, and I am running a GTX560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set the graphics to high, causing some sluggishness, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I lowered the settings to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm merely lucky with game issues, but it seems that most negative reviews sound like they come from some really entitled people.

+RPG leveling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) -subpar AI teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of leveling skills (no branching). Listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for Universe is easily the star, but Big Fight for Beef is also very good.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to coincide with the WEF's event in Davos.

As the deadline nears for the Fiat-GM deal, Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. This deadline marks when Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wishes to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on takeover hopes. The US firm is believed to be offering about $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. GM has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 alliance resulted from a competitive race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes Iraq war: billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease." The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars, as UK talents didn't secure acting or directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" didn't win the director or screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton did not receive a prize. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress award to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo did not win Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film Award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who presented children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, expressed feeling "totally overwhelming" upon winning. "Wasp" tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic "Halloween," has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide—a record for independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and advanced through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she started working with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 70s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It states that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It revealed that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even confessed to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, the report argues, broadband encourages people to take a more active role online.

Yukos is heading back to U.S. courts. The Russian oil and gas company is due in court on Thursday, continuing its battle for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., aiming to leverage international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft, but this occurred only after the state auction faced disruptions. Yukos's lawyers argue that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders are determined to pursue legal action against any entity that acquires its assets.

Voters flock to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, which celebrate the best web blogs—online spaces where people share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it temporarily closed due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the best regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a significant year, with a top U.S. dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to the U.S. research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its massive dams, the Chinese state press reports. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale projects ordered to halt due to insufficient environmental checks. The Beijing News mentioned the company might opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop construction at two other projects—the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges Project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to complete mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne accidentally volleyed over David James' head into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance by shooting wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United looked unlikely to secure the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more labored than patient, creating just one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but assured that the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats stated Dr. Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, mentioned NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One major problem that had faced Ms. Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come. Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought composure to the midfield, which we needed and which no other player has.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," it will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 February. The film features Michael discussing his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film includes Michael talking about his early days in Wham! and his later career, touching on his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from music download sales, which were previously part of a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales will be included in the UK singles chart later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These sales, along with sales of physical singles and airplay data, will now be combined in the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also integrates airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit a spammer hard as the net's self-proclaimed spam king seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions in damages. The company stated that filing for Chapter 11 would help it attempt to resolve its legal problems while continuing to operate. Ranked as the third-biggest spammer worldwide by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has refuted claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a personality clash at White Hart Lane. Newspapers speculated that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The sole reason for his resignation is personal problems. He recently spoke to me, stating this matter is purely personal." Arnesen mentioned he could not shed light on the issues that led Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added, "Jacques has never specified what those issues were. But I trust him, and we must accept it. I think we should respect his decision.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but again struggled to turn pressure into points.

The focus on the economy for the election battle is central to Britain’s future, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He spoke after cabinet members held their last meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement. He said voters would recognize that Labour had brought stability and growth and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture," and the Lib Dems provided more details on their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition over who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to Run at AAA's in Sheffield

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy aims to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has shown tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment, with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson aims for dual success. England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has targeted dual code victories over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international, switched codes in 2000 and now leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later, at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England has the opportunity to secure their third autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, and also to avenge June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of losses against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Internet users are being warned to avoid a scam website that falsely claims to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate by mimicking an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no connection with the fraudulent site and has reported it to the police. This site is just the latest in a series of scams exploiting goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. A link to the website is included in a spam email currently circulating. The email's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal," and its text is marked by the poor grammar and bad spelling characteristic of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids are being invited from local, Arab, and international companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications announced. The winner will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry stated that it aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also seeks to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunication sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. Furthermore, a roadshow for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to internet security as older individuals and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware increased by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, commissioned by net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are reaching a diverse range of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those purchasing home internet security programs are retired. Over the last three years, this has risen by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) are buying security software compared to retired men. The research highlights the changing stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as the growing awareness of the increased risks that high-speed broadband connections can pose.

Podcasts signify the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs—a vast amount of space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners are filling that space with audio content from an array of unpredictable producers. This phenomenon is called "podcasting," and its most ardent supporter is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting derives its name from the Apple iPod, though owning an iPod is not necessary to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show typically produced in the comfort of one's home. All you need is a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. Podcasters upload their creations to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them, entirely free of charge.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has had her book "Small Island" win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has received the children's fiction award for the third time for "Not the End of the World." All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to decide the overall winner, announced later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed Levy's London-based novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' U.S. lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a U.S. court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal - which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction - has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts completed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from the goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service allowing customers who require substantial computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. Grid computing is the latest buzzword in a company that believes computing capacity is as vital a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature like utilities such as electricity and water, said Sun's COO Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigots

Scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to strike them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson explained that exclusion orders are among several measures being considered in the Scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts to tackle the problem. However, the minister emphasized that eliminating sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long linked with certain sections of support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth made an appearance at the British premiere of the new film "Beyond the Sea" in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, not only wrote and directed the film but also starred in it, drawing inspiration from the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I believe was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, performs all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, portrays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, accompanied by her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom, at the premiere.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Fri) Headingley, Friday, 25 February, 2000 GMT. The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley proceeded after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones are facing an uncertain future; the fixed line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia indicates that more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now use only a mobile phone. It revealed that people retain their fixed line phones due to lower call charges, but most respondents believed the future is undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted that mobiles and fixed phones are used for different purposes. Home phones are used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tend to be shorter, primarily between mobile users and friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents said they prefer their fixed phone because it remains cheaper to use than a mobile.

MPs Tout Lords Replacement Plan

A group of MPs has increased the pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber where 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to reach an agreement on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group states it can garner support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditaries due to likely failure following opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that consensus is necessary for reforms. There have been suggestions of proposals to change at least the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Disappointed Scott in solid start: Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M. Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his performance in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 secs but ran 0.04 secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming its printer ink cartridges expire on a set date. The woman from Georgia alleges a chip inside the cartridge signals the printer for refilling, even when unnecessary. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the U.S. who bought an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise users to change them. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcasts. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the world’s first station to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website to enable the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music will perform at June's Isle of Wight Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as a headliner for the three-day event, occurring from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday night. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album "Avalon." Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other successes including "Street Life," "Love is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for aid match Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the northern hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the northern team against Rod Macqueen's southern hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

The comedy "Sideways" has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, with Alexander Payne winning Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. Acting awards also went to stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, boasting five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners include Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner'; he earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer amassed $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to the center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Walmart fights back at accusers; two major US companies have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Walmart, took out more than 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The group aims to counter criticism over its pay deals, benefits packages, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly plans a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart began its efforts with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are lots of 'urban legends' circulating these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

Tories outlining policing plans would ask local communities to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities but not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems warned the plan could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory promises. Responding to the plans, the Chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence. Jan Berry stated: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every election. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she cautioned.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have introduced plans for health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high TB incidence, they would need a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will undergo a full medical examination. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would automatically result in visa applications being denied. All other conditions would be addressed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes. Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

Doves soar to the UK album summit as the Manchester rock band enters the UK album chart at number one with their new release, Some Cities. The trio replaces the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with Over and Over, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's The Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Hip-hop performer Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Davies favors Gloucester future; Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with the English side Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands that the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to stay put. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to receive a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies out in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry about the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without major council tax increases. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is expected to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford stated that nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club look to Africa. Four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are ready to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin are the first Arab side ever to compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief period with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. They have a strong ethic and actively promote peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll': more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, says cutting the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared with 2003. He estimates this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design offers a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Instead of sensing voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for voltage to return to its baseline. This removes the necessity for power-hungry, large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would voluntarily allow control by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, while the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond bringing larger and more tangible objects into a quantum behavior regime, this capability has spurred ideas of using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, and as precision force sensors functioning beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the essentially linear interaction between motion and light or electricity prevents access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals highlighted the potential to overcome this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer product evaluations that help customers make informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have developed increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies in response to deployed detectors. These strategies are difficult to track, as they can change rapidly over time, differ among spammers and target products, and often remain unknown. Additionally, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which doesn't align well with the goal of preserving the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors compete based on practical goals beyond just detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game result in stable detectors that are resilient to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive solutions leading to exact transfer, where solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we explore the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even for well-separated mixtures. We show that all local minima share a structural similarity, partially identifying the component centers of the true mixture. Each local minimum involves a unique combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to cases where the true mixture components meet a certain separation condition and remain valid even with over- or under-specified component numbers. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, our findings yield sharper results regarding scaling with the separation between components.

We examine the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, specified by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, utilizes another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is crafted as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope, dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We present simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was conducted using existing models in the literature, such as those of Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is integrated into a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition behavior. The experimental data results, for various speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a crucial factor in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences, and laboratories of Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on time regularization, maintaining the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. We use a high-order MVS scheme that allows integration with large time steps when far from close encounters.
